text: We find Frances and Sophie, both 27, setting up a little performance space in front of a statue.
Okay, ready?
Yep. Sophie sings and plays a shitty guitar badly. Frances dances. When people walk by, they both stop and yell:
Give us your MONEY!!! They laugh. Sometimes someone will give them change. Usually a creepy guy.
(alone now) Give us-- (laughs) Come on!
Give us your money!!! CUT TO: Music swells.

Frances and Sophie run through the park together. They 3 dump what little money they earned into another musician's guitar case. Frances makes sure to keep a dollar bill. They run into the subway. 4 Subway. Sophie sits. Frances stands above her. She 5 leans down to say something. Frances cooks. Scrambled eggs and stir fry. Sophie 6 enters frame and gets plates out of the cupboard.  10
I tried a frittata but it’s more of a scramble. Frances is reading and Sophie is knitting. 7

Oh, this is interesting. She reads a sentence out loud from “Sincerity and Authenticity” by Lionel Trilling. Sophie nods. Sophie works out to a video in the tiny living room. 8 Frances half watches. Frances and Sophie smoke in two separate adjacent 9 windows. They both lean outside. We see them talking outside the windows. They sit across from each other in their living room. 10
(doing a Jamaican accent) Okay, my father is from Jamaica, mon, and-- (doing an Irish accent) --my mother is from Ireland. (trying to combine the accents) So I talk like this... They both crack up.

(doing a Russian accent) My mother is from Russia and-- (doing a Southern accent) --and my father is from Alabama. (trying to combine) So I talk like this. They play a game together. 10A They do their laundry at the laundromat across the 11 street. They both lie in bed and watch The Day After Tomorrow on the computer. Sophie falls asleep first and Frances quietly puts the computer away. Frances makes a move out of the bed.
(eyes closed) Don’t be stupid.
I should sleep in my own bed.
Why?
Because I bought it.
Stay. But take off your socks.
Okay...Thank you.
Shut up.  13
CLOSE on a photo of a bony, bug-eyed cat that resembles 1 an alien.
It’s hairless?

No, it has fine curly hair. CLOSE on Frances looking down. She looks up briefly, attempts a smile and looks back down. CLOSE on her hand touching the back of her neck. She stares at a photograph in her lap. She is wearing dance clothes underneath a knit dress, and her hair is pulled back. A bulky canvas backpack sits beside her. She’ll have it the whole film. CLOSE on her fingers smoothing the skin on her arm.

(excited) There’s this house in Westchester, the basement is all Cornish Rexes, it smells awful, the top floor is Siamese cats. She nods and hands Dan, early 30’s, back the photo. He sits opposite her on a thrift-store couch, a manilla envelope in his lap.
I’m allergic to cats.
They're hypo-allergenic. (quick smile) This is a special Frances kitty.
Oh...who knew? He passes her back a photo.
This one is the runt. Which is cheaper but I think is the best one anyway. I figured one runt and one regular?  Frances hesitates.
I put a hundred dollar down payment on each cat...or eighty for the runt and a hundred for the other one. Pause.
Why not get one cat?
A cat needs a buddy. If you get one cat you need to get two cats.

I‘1l give you two hundred dollars to get no cats. He nods, somewhat hurt and annoyed, glances back at the photo of the runt, starts stacking the photos and tucking them back into the envelope. Frances comes over and sits next to him, puts her hand on his back.
So, who will take care of them if you go away?
I thought...we’d get them together.
And move them back and forth between our apartments?
No...I thought maybe you could move in with me... Frances hesitates.
(strangely) Oh, wow...
Do you want to move in with me?
Yeah.
Yeah?
Yes. (pause) I mean, I do have this other thing.
What “other thing?”
Well...I don’t know. I promised Sophie I'd stay through the lease. He sighs deeply.
Is that bad? I’m sorry. I feel bad.
Can’t she find someone else?
Yeah. But, it’s my friend...
Uh huh.
I want to move in with you.
Okay.
I feel bad.
Don’t feel bad. Forget it.
No... (off his expression) What?
Nothing.
You're mad.
I’m not mad. I’m disappointed.
I feel bad.
Stop feeling bad, Frances! I asked you to move in, you said, No. Her phone rings.
But I can’t.
You can, you don’t want to. She looks at her phone. She does.
Who is it?
It’s okay, I don’t need to get it.
Who is it?
It’s Sophie. I’11 call her back.
Just pick up the phone.
Do you mind?
(frustrated) Answer it.

(into phone, a voice) Hey girl...waz up wid you? Where you at?...I can’t come now... (laugh) Are you drunk?...I can’t...I love you... Dan watches her without expression. He gets up and gets a beer from the fridge. She hangs He drinks
(laughs) Dumpling house!...I love you...I can’t really talk now...I love you...Okay!...I love you. up and looks at him somewhat sheepishly.
She's with Benji and Lev at this party in Chinatown. (pause) They’re drunk. his beer.
I don’t know...maybe this isn’t working.
I’m sorry.
Me too.
(a new idea) Maybe... (pause) Forget it.
What?
I do want to pay you for the cats.
I’m not going to take money from you. But I’m going to get the cats anyway.
But then you’re going to be a single guy with two cats.
Why...why am I going to be single?
With two cats.
No, I know. I mean why would I be single?
I don’t know... I thought you said this wasn’t working. I mean, if we don’t move in together. If we can’t move in together.
We can move in together.
I don’t know...I don’t know if I believe anything I’m saying.
Uh huh. (pause) This hasn’t been great for a while.
(nods ) This hasn’t been great for a while. This has not... She looks at him sadly. Frances puts on a too-big bomber jacket, not really cool, just something a friend gave her
Where are you going?
I guess home. I’m really tired. I’m always so tired. She puts on her backpack.
(sadly) Let’s move in together.  14 15 16 17 10.

CLOSE on Frances (wearing the same clothes). She walks through a crowd and leans in to Sophie. Sophie is talking to Benji and Lev. WIDER: They drink, dance in a silly way, laugh. Lev plays a record. He tries very hard to flirt with Frances.
I can't get interested in art or books or movies about animals. Animals in conversation. The animals have to talk or be at war for me to be interested.
No one is on the platform. Frances pulls down her pants and pees into the tracks, holding onto the pillar to suspend her bare bottom out over the track. Sophie looks for a train. She turns to see--
(laughing) Don’t hit the third rail! Sophie’s attention goes to an MTA flyer posted.
Shit! The three’s not running!
Frances lying in Sophie’s lap.
Frances, in her same clothes, smokes a cigarette by the open window. Sophie, sleep-wear on, sits next to her with her legs propped up on the sill. Sophie extends her hand for the cigarette.
I want a sip.
Do you want your own?  11.
I want a sip. Frances reluctantly hands it over.
The coffee people are right. We are like a lesbian couple that doesn’t have sex anymore. Sophie hands it back and exits frame.
Wait! Come back!
Don’t pick at your face.
(kind of to herself, touching a pimple) I don’t like smoking alone. She puts out her own cigarette and follows Sophie to the bedroom. Sophie is writing an email on her phone.
Me and Dan don’t have sex anymore...didn’t have sex anymore.
Yeah, that’s why you broke up.
Or if it happened then he would just - he only had one way that he could finish.
I hate that. 18 Sophie enters the bathroom. Washes her face. 18
It was always with me facing flat on the bed from behind. Which just...everything that matters was covered up.
It’s like with me and Patch -  12.
(making fun) Yo Patchy!
(also making fun) ‘Sup bra? (continue, matter of fact) The way he always likes to come in my face.
Yeah, CLASSY. Patch is the kind of dude who says “I gotta take a leak.”
(cringing) And wears pre-distressed baseball hats. But...he’s a nice guy...for today. Frances joins Sophie in the bathroom.
I should feel bad that I went to the party.
You deserved it. You just got out of relationship jail.
I think Dan was an alcoholic.
He was. Sophie leaves frame.
He wasn’t a real alcoholic. Frances leaves frame.
But sometimes he would have twelve beers. 19 Sophie lies in bed. She’s still typing on her phone. 1
Stop playing on your phone.  13. Frances flops down into bed next to her.
It’s the only thing with interweb in this house. I have to answer work emails.
(to herself) The neighbors changed their code.
(re: her phone) Hey!
What?
Lev is asking for your number.
Give it to him!
(not judgemental) You did just break up with Dan today.
Just do it. She types in the number. Frances gets her phone from a bag and stares at it. Waiting. Sophie goes back to typing on her phone. Frances’ phone chirps. Reads out loud.
“Ahoy sexy. Are you around this week?” Ahoy sexy?
That is actually very gay.
Am I nautically sensual?
You’re funny.
Lev didn’t laugh at any of my jokes tonight.  14.
You are SO funny.
Should I text back “Starboard anal sex?” Sophie laughs. Puts her phone down. Snuggles down in bed.
(settling) No.
Tell me the story of us...
Again? Well, Frances, we are going to take over the world...
.+-You’ll be this awesomely bitchy publishing mogul...
...And you’1ll be a famous modern dancer and I'll publish a really expensive book about you...
...That d-bags we make fun of buy to put on their coffee tables...
+.-and we co-own a vacation apartment in Paris...
.-.and we will have lovers...
--.and no children...
..-and we will speak at college graduations...
...and honorary degrees!
...SO many honorary degrees.  20 21 22 15.
Sophie and Frances are asleep in the same bed.
Frances warms up alone in an empty studio. While holding a position, Frances notices a woman pass by the open doorway.
Frances pops her head into the outer office.
Hey! Colleen, 40’s, beautiful, retired dancer - drops everything she’s holding.
Jesus!
Sorry. I’m here.
I don’t really have time to talk, I’m doing the job of three people here, but I can see you after rehearsal.
I read that article in the Times -- you must be so happy!
Oh yeah, thanks, I forget I make my own work sometimes, but thanks.
I usually hate that woman’s writing.
Right. Well, thank you Frances.
I actually, I had a couple of questions. I’m trying to be pro- active about my life.  16.
(getting it) I’'ll see if I have some studio openings for choreography time --
-- Uh, no. I wanted to know if there were any more classes at the school that I could teach...I’ma little, I’m kind of broke.
I’1l check, but I’m all full I think --
-- I thought so, I’m just proud of myself for asking.
Well, we’ll probably use you and some other apprentices for the Christmas show, so, that’s something.
That’s GREAT. Frances just stands there.
I just wanted to say I really look up to you, and I just, I think you're great.
Ha! A beat-up old dancer doing paperwork? Frances still stands there a little goofily. Colleen decides to wrap it up:
I really need to do all that paperwork now - I’m running rehearsal today so I’ll see you in there.
Bye. Frances disappears.  23 24 25 26 27 17.
About twenty two dancers are rehearsing. Colleen runs the rehearsal. Frances is paired with Rachel, 25, about her height and build. They laugh and talk in between working.
Do you have more gum?

What? No. (taking the gum out of her mouth) I don’t even know where this gum came from. Frances dances behind her, mirroring her movements. Other pairs of dancers do the same. Colleen claps her hands:
Understudies, out! Frances and a few others go to the side and watch the primary company dance.
Frances teaches ballet to a group of young girls.
Frances shops.
Frances goes uptown. Clutching two huge grocery bags.
Frances waits outside a building, watching people exit. She sees Sophie.
(laughing)

Sophie and Frances eat. The park is almost deserted. It’s twilight and too cold for a picnic. They have pushed several tables together and made a banquet table and spread everything out. They toast two Pellegrino bottles.
On the subway. Sophie keeps checking her phone.
No service.
Sometimes there is, for a second...
What is going on with that phone, lady?
I didn’t want to do it without knowing it was okay with you first.
Do what?

(putting her phone away) I want to move into this apartment with Phoebe. It’s this great apartment in the West Village which is what I’ve always wanted and you know that but I don’t want to do it if you’re not okay with it --
Oh --
But they need to know by tomorrow. So I kind of need to tell them something today...
Who have you been emailing?
My parents, for help with the broker's fee and stuff. 28 29  Revision (05/14/2012) 19.
You have to pay OUR rent.
I know and I’1l pay until the end of the lease but it’s only for another two months anyway. Are you okay with it? I really don’t want to do it if you’re not okay with it.
I sort of thought we were going to renew the lease.
Yeah, but we never talked about it.
I could have moved in with Dan.
Not if you broke up.
That’s why we broke up.
Really?
No.
It’s LITERALLY on my favorite street. Phoebe said it was too good to pass up.
You hate Phoebe.
She’s okay.
We make fun of her.
She said I'd always regret it if I don't just go for it.
Then go for it.  Revision (05/14/2012) 20.
We're both really clean.
I said go for it.
I wish it was going to be with you.
Yeah.
But Phoebe found the place.
Right.
Is this train skipping DeKalb? She gets up to look at the subway map.
We could look for another place together, if you want, but it’s really hard to find stuff in the West Village.
I can’t afford the West Village.
I know it’s so expensive. My raise just barely covers the rent.
You should take the place.
I’m not leaving you - I’m just moving neighborhoods. Frances’s eyes well up.
Are you okay?
Yeah. Totally. Frances is messing with her hand.  30 21.
What are you doing?
I just put my ring on my thumb and I’m having trouble getting it off.
Hold your hand over your head. It‘’ll drain the blood out. Frances does.
I look like I’m asking a question.
I’m not doing anything wrong. Our lease was going to be up in two months anyway. They ride in silence, Frances’ hand over her head.

head_text.subj: INT. FRANCES AND SOPHIE'S APARTMENT. DAYS LATER. MORNING

text: Frances gets a tea bag out and puts it in a mug. She rattles around the cabinets looking for a kettle. Not finding a kettle, she boils water in a saucepan. While she’s waiting for the water to boil, she lights a cigarette. The apartment is nearly empty. It turns out Sophie had most of the furniture and Frances had most of the books. It looks like the crack den of a pretty well educated junkie. The water boils. Frances tries to pour it into the mug, but scalds herself. She kicks the kitchen cabinet. Frances is on the phone. She moves.
(on the phone) We bought the kettle TOGETHER! REMEMBER? At the Mexican superstore? Jesus! BRING IT BACK. OR BUY ME ANOTHER KETTLE.  31 32 33 22.
Mailbox. Frances is checking the mail. Sees something she likes. Tax rebate! Whoops and runs out onto the street.
Frances leaves the bank. Is still elated. Looks around, unsure what to do next. Her elation leaves her slightly. She pulls out her phone and scrolls. Half shrugs, calls someone.
Hey I just got a tax rebate, want to go out to dinner?!
Lev (from the party) is scrolling through his phone. He finds the photo he was looking for and hands the phone to Frances across the table.
This is me in the locker room of the Knicks.
Wow!
Sophie said you liked basketball.
That was just one time. Frances changes the picture.
Wow! Crazy!
(looking at the picture) Oh, yeah, I was goofing around on this Vintage Triumph I think I’m going to buy.
Motorcycles are so loud.
What?
I mean, you can’t listen to music while you’re on a motorcycle.
But you’re on a motorcycle. Lev takes back his phone, finds a new picture.
Check it. This is me with Jay Leno.
He’s such a dick.
I know, but don’t you just love him? The waitress comes up to give them the check. Frances grabs it and puts her credit card in.
No!
Yes!
No...I mean, YES! I’m the one with the tax rebate!
Can I take this?
Yes!
Oh...fine. The waitress leaves.
Just because you bought dinner doesn’t mean I’m going to sleep with you.
(not getting it) I’m not trying to sleep with you...  24.
No, I’m pretending to be a liberated woman.
Oh, got it.
Thanks for paying. That was very sweet. You’re a lady. He takes her hand. She lets him. The waitress comes back. Frances immediately withdraws her hand.
I’m sorry, but the card didn’t go through, do you have another card you want to try?
Oh, shit! Sorry, yes, um, this is a debit card?
Only credit cards or cash.
Okay. (to Lev) I’m so embarrassed, I’m not a real person yet.
I got it.
(getting up from the table) No, no, no, I’m just going to go run and get some cash.
Frances hustles down the street, looking for an ATM.
Frances runs in.
Where is your ATM?
Not working. No ATM.  36 37 38 39 25.
She looks for a bank or something. She stops a woman.
Do you know where a bank is?
Um, there’s a Bank of America about five blocks up.

Frances punches in her pin in the ATM area of a closed B of A while a homeless man looks on. “Do you accept the $3.00 service charge?” She sighs, her finger hovering over the button, accepts. As she passes the homeless guy:
Sorry, sorry...
Frances runs back to the restaurant. Falls. Hard. Gets up and keeps running.
The restaurant is considerably more cleared out. Frances has been gone a long time. She sits down plunks the money down, happy. Lev is on the phone.
I’1ll ask her and let you know...okay, man, see you. He hangs up.
Sorry, that was Benji. You know, my Sophie. Frances is flushed and out of breath.
You go to Switzerland?  40 26.
(breathing heavy) Have I been to Switzerland? No.
No, did you go to -- I mean, where were you?

I’m sorry, I had so much trouble finding -- She casually picks up the last bit of her wine and downs it. She puts her glass down, and wipes at her face with the napkin. She looks at the napkin, it has streaks of red.
What the fuck? She tries to trace the blood up her arm to its source.
You're bleeding.
I can’t find it.
Somewhere on your arm... She feels her arm, trying to figure it out. Her elbow.
Shit. Sorry.
Don’t apologize to me.
Oh, damn it. Oh, let me, I’m going to go to the bathroom, just one second. INT. LEV AND BENJI’S APARTMENT. NIGHT. 40 Frances stands in their apartment. Totally enamored with it.
This place is pretty awesome. Lev enters with a First Aid Kit.  27.
I’m a First Responder.
You didn’t have to do that.
(opening the Bandaid) You're injured.
I know, but I’m fine. He places the bandage on her arm.
There.
Like a boy scout... Sophie makes fun of me because I can’t account for my bruises. We’re not living together anymore.
Really?
Yeah, I’m going to have to find a place to live. I can’t afford to stay there alone. I was kind of thinking Washington Heights...?
(lighting a cigarette) The chick crashing in the little room might be moving to Portland next month.
Oh, that’s good to know. (then) You smoke inside?
Yeah, don’t you?
No.
Want to?  4l 42 28. He offers her a cigarette. Lights it for her with a special lighter.
This makes me feel like a bad mother in 1987.
Wanna see my room? INT. LEV’S ROOM. MOMENTS LATER. 41 Frances is looking at the framed pictures on the wall. They are old and yellowed.
Is this your family?

Nope. They are quiet a little too long. Lev moves towards her and puts his hand on her shoulder. Frances glances at the hand, and instantly makes a face and a strange noise that is definitely negative. It’s something that if she had thought about for one second more that she wouldn’t have done. Lev moves away. They hear Benji come through the door. He has two girls with him. They make a lot of noise.
Oh my GOD! This place is AMAZING!

Benji’s home. INT. LEV AND BENJI’S APARTMENT. LIVING ROOM. A LITTLE 42 LATER. One girl dances to music. Lev plays cribbage with another girl. Flirting heavily with her - looking at her cards, teasing her. Benji and Frances are talking. Frances drinks a scotch out of a proper scotch glass.  29.
I love dance. I dated a dancer in high school and her teacher said I could have really had a future in it.
(joking but serious) You liar. He’s a liar.
No I’m not! Ask anyone from school! (to Frances) I really to love dance.
It’s pretty great...I mean it’s a hard world, but -
Do us a dance!
I feel weird...
Just one move. Frances gets up does something quickly and sits back down.
That was GREAT!
You should be in this music video my friend is working on. I‘'11 hook you guys up.
(to herself) You guys are...like magic.
Is Noodle Champion still open? I’m starving.
I don’t think so...
All we have is...we have eggs. I want something PREPARED. And BROUGHT to me.  43 44 45 46

Wait! INT. LEV AND BENJI’S APARTMENT. KITCHEN. LATER Frances has the stove going with a couple of items. INT. LEV AND BENJI’S APARTMENT. LIVING ROOM. LATER Frances serves everyone omelettes prettily. People compliment her and the food.
It’s Sophie’s recipe, but... She does a little twirl of happiness. INT. LEV AND BENJI’S APARTMENT. LIVING ROOM. LATER. The other two girls leave. Kiss everyone on the cheek.
(to his girl) I’1l call you. We’1l shoot some pigeons.
And I‘1l1 let you know about my show.
Yes! Please! I love your hair.
Thanks. Everyone’s gone, Frances moves to the couch between Lev and Benji.
This is the best night I’ve had since Sophie dumped me. She basks in it.
(nods, half-hearted) I should probably go, too.
Make a left and a left out of the building and the F is on the other side of the bridge on East Broadway. 30. 43 44 45 46  Revision (05/14/2012)
You'll see a 99 Cent Store --
Okay, yeah. I should go. (beat, indicating the extra room) Is that chick really moving to Portland?
Yeah.
Before you go, do another dance.
(this time eager) Ok! She gets up and starts to dance. The boys love it. 31.  47 48 49 50 32.

Music swells. Frances runs through the streets of Chinatown, bomber jacket and backpack on. She’s running, almost dancing through the streets. She bursts into the apartment. INT. BEDROOM. NIGHT. Frances is asleep. She hears people having sex. She opens her eyes, stirs. Closes her eyes.
The two boys, Benji and Lev, run into the bedroom and jump on top of her bed, play-tickling her and body slamming her. It’s morning.
Benji on his computer, smoking a cigarette. Still in a T- shirt and pajama bottoms. Frances on her computer, backpack on, ready to leave. Both drinking Folgers instant coffee.
What time did you get in last night?
Um, late. Like 1:00.
Why didn’t you come in and say hi?
I’m sorry -- I thought you were asleep.
I wasn’t asleep. I heard you come in.
Then you knew what time I got in?
(ignoring her question) I’m working on some sample skits for Saturday Night Live. (MORE )
I know a producer there who said I could probably get a job writing for them.
Cool.
That’s such a lie. Lev has come out of his room. Fully dressed, bare feet. A girl, Nessa, trails after him. She’s about twenty. Very thin. Not wearing pants, just underwear and a big t- shirt.
Guys. This is Nessa.
Hey.
(putting out her hand to shake) Hello. I’m Frances.
Lev and I were going to make bacon egg bagels. You want some?
Oh, no. Thanks though. I wanted to go to the Met and drop this laundry off and I need to deposit a check, a whole...Sunday planned.
Frances eats a very large egg bagel very quickly. So quickly that she nearly chokes. Her backpack is now off. She notices how much faster she’s eating than everyone else. Slows down. Or tries to.
Why do you all live together?
Well, I knew Benji through Sophie and -
Where is Sophie these days?
Busy with work.  34.
Which Sophie?
Sophie Kozak?
Get out! I fucked her little brother!
Oh, yeah, you fucked Thomas?
You fucked who?
(to Frances) How do you know her?
We went to college together and we're...we were born together.
Oh you’re that Frances.
Who is Thomas?
Not really but that’s what we say. (beat) Yeah, I’m that Frances.
You should know she speaks so highly of you.
Right. I mean, we're best friends. She’s been to my house for Christmas three times.
Why doesn’t she go to her house?
(annoyed) She’s Jewish.
She was saying last week how much she loves you.  35.
You saw her last week?
When did you fuck her brother?
Where were you guys?
(to Lev) I met you last night. (then to Frances) We were at that restaurant Po.
Who were you fucking last week, Lev?
What...is that a good restaurant? Was she with...who was she with?
Me and Thomas and that guy she dates, Patch?
Double date.
And some girl. Esme.
Phoebe. Cunt.
Who were you fucking last week Frances?
(joking) I make love.
Frances: UNDATEABLE! Nessa is thinking about something. Puzzled.
Yeah. Aren’t you a lot older than Sophie?  52 36.
No. We went to college together.
You seem older.
I’m a couple months older.
You seem a LOT older. But less, like, grown up. It’s weird. You have an older face...
.--but like you don’t have your shit together.
Frances lays on the couch, shoes off. Benji still on the computer. Lev is standing by the door, holding a motorcycle helmet.
(a little sadly) Nessa can’t come from sex. Only sixty-nine.
That’s a crazy helmet.
Got to. Motorcycle law. Oh, can you leave that rent check for me?
Yeah, yeah, sorry. I'll put it on your desk. It’s for...$950?
I...I don’t, I thought we said $950 when I moved in.
Nope. The whole space is $4000 but the little room is only $1200
But, I --  37.
No, she’s right. We said she could pay that much until she got more cash together.
Remember because when I do the Christmas show I’11 make more because I’1l be doing like ten shows a week...
Oh right right.
So we're good with $950? That’s okay? I’m really sorry... He puts down his motorcycle visor.
No prob. Catch you on the flipside! Lev leaves.
He leaves so easily...
Transportation is his thing. Bike, skateboard. He has a car, too.
I can’t even get out of the house on my feet! She is quietly dejected.
You know what Virginia Woolf book this reminds me of?
Frances: UNDATEABLE. Frances laughs.
Wanna watch a movie?
Now?  38.
Yeah, let’s do a movie afternoon.
I already wasted the whole day - I already feel bad about the day.
I think it’s a great day. I ate an egg bagel that Lev’s slut made me. I internet acquired three pairs of very rare Ray Bans. I’m doing awesome.
I thought we were both broke!
I caved and finally took a loan from my step dad. Bastard. I need a fucking job, though.
What about SNL?
Yeah, maybe. It’s gone so downhill. Goes to the bar. Looks at his watch. Pours himself a scotch.
Until then, it’s after three. I can drink. Let’s do something fun. We could go to a movie.
Movies are so expensive now...I should be saving so I can pay full rent.
I’m not going to force you.
(getting up, ready) I have to work out, at least. I cannot get fat. Frances puts on shoes, etc. Benji drinks his scotch and starts going through his records to pick one.  53 54 39.
Do I look old to you?
No. Yes. How old?
Older than I am? Older than twenty- seven?

No. Twenty-seven is old, though. CUT TO: It’s dark out. Benji and Frances watch a movie. 5 Benji smokes and eats an egg roll. Frances wolfs down a box of General Tso’s Chicken. We'll be coming back to New York a lot, we'll just be based in Tokyo.
You’11l learn Japanese.
We can video chat. 21st century, what up.  Revision (05/14/2012) 75.
My computer doesn’t have that.
New places are good for you, I think.
(observing the chain restaurant around her) Yeah.
You should travel, Fran.
I am. (lies for some reason) I’m going to. (nearly crying, genuine) I'm happy for you, I just...no, you know what? I’m just happy for you.
We're going to have a blog.
Together?
Yeah, BARF. We'll upload pictures and stories and stuff.
Homeless and vacation have some similarities.
I’m so sorry I missed your Christmas show...I guess I was mad.
-- it’s okay. I didn’t...it wasn’t so good anyway.
How’s all that going?
Um, pretty good. Great. I havea meeting on Monday with Colleen to talk about stuff.  Revision (05/14/2012) 76.
You'll finally be in the company? For real?
Yeah, I’1l probably be touring, though.
That’s so great Fran.
(letting her assume) Yeah, it is.
Where are you living? I heard you're not with the boys anymore. Hey, you wanna live in our apartment while we’re in Japan?
No. I. No. (pause, deciding) I’m going to have my own place real soon.
Maybe one day I’1l stay with you!
Maybe. Um, I should go. (beat) Thanks for calling, Sophie. I'm...I’m sorry too.
Apology accepted.
(bristling) Well, don’t be a dick about it!
I wasn't!
I mean this phone call is costing me a fortune!
(lying) . ; Just kidding. It isn’t. Hey, is Abby in Paris now, do you know?
I think so.
Okay.
You sound really good Frances.

I am. I am really good. Thanks for calling. I’m going to say something but I’m going to hang up right after because I don’t want you to feel obligated to say something back. I love you Sophie bye. She hangs up hastily.
99 Frances looks at the times for whatever lame American mov are playing. EXT. She EXT. She INT. Her INT.
When did X-Men start?
walks more. Looks at her phone. Nothing.
puts her key in the lock...
phone alarm goes off. Frances startles.
Frances reads a fashion magazine.

head_text.subj: INT. CAB FROM JFK. LATE DAY

text: Frances sits in the back. suddenly lights up with a message. She looks exhausted. She listens. 100 101 102 103 104 Her phone  105 106 78. ABBY’S MESSAGE Frances, honey, we just got your messages, I don't know why they didn't come through before. We're here! We'd love to see you. This is total kismet: You remember Gerard, Nicholas's brother? The one who looks like Jean Pierre Leaud? Well, he's divorced now and staying with us. I think you'd really like him. Come to dinner tonight, he'll be there, as well as a philosopher and painter couple who are really great... Oh, what great timing. Frances hangs up her phone.
Frances sits in a waiting area. She’s dressed in dance clothes. Colleen pokes her head out of the office.
Hey, you, come on in! INT. COLLEEN’S OFFICE 106 Colleen moves behind her desk. Frances sits.
Rachel said you were in Paris.
I was.
You’re back so soon.
Well, we had our meeting.
We could have moved it. I almost cancelled it myself this morning-- I woke up with a tickle in my throat. Frances nods. Silence.
Do you want to take over Nancy’s position?
What?
Nancy's pregnant.
Oh, no. I don’t. Who told you that?
No, I’m asking you. I mean, I assumed you’re not keeping on with the company. Frances hesitates. It’s so hard to hear that.
(sympathetic) I know it’s hard, but it’s probably best.
(not sure why she’s agreeing) Yeah.
You don’t want to be an apprentice for the rest of your life.
Nope.
You know, you should think about putting your own stuff together.
Like how?
Like your own work.
Eh, I don’t know, I kind of stopped doing it after college. And that was basically, like, cheerleaders doing my choreography.
I always liked the stuff you did, even for the kids. 79.  80.
Yeah?
Listen, you should think about taking Nancy’s position. It’s not a lot of money, but it’s enough to keep you going...
Why would I do that?
Just a good day job while you figure out if you want to choreograph or what.
You're saying it like it’s easy.
No, it’s not easy. But if you worked here you could use the studio space -
- I'll get something else. (lying) . I’m really close to getting something.
A job?
Yeah. Dancing. I’m still going to be a dancer, just not here.
Oh. Good for you. That’s great.
I know.
Well, good luck Frances.
Yeah. Good luck to you, too.  107 Revision (05/14/2012) 81.
Frances hikes. Alone. Breathing and walking. Lots of tree She gets to the top of something. Gets out her phone. Cal
Hi Mom.
Hi Mom.
PAUL PICK UP THE OTHER PHONE. How is it up there?
Good, good. I’m dancing - kind of - .-+-and I’m living in a dorm I never got to live in before, which is fun. All the RA’s live in dorms.

head_text.subj: NOT THE ONE IN THE LIVING ROOM THE

text: BATTERY IS DEAD. Is it strange to be back?
No - it’s kind of nice. It’s so empty in the summer. It’s weird - it’s like I went back to college but everyone was a dancer and not a semiotics major.
That must be fun for you, though.
--and now I’m one of the adults...I keep thinking I’m going to run into Sophie.
(getting on the phone) Hi honey!
Sophie e-mailed me a picture of her and Patch in the largest dog park in the world - I think I'd really like that about Japan.
I got a picture of them at a porn mall.
Do you have enough money?
Yeah, I mean, I’m still in debt from Paris. That was just stupid.
I’m sorry we can’t help out.
You help out so much. I’11 be okay. They pay me extra to work the events.
You aren’t a good waitress.
It’s not waitressing, it’s, like, pouring. For donors.
Are you choreographing?
Paul, we went over this!
At least you can’t spend money in nature.
Where are you right now?
Nature.
Frances is in a T-Shirt that says “ASK ME!” Another girl on the same T-Shirt.  83.
We don’t have to, like, guide them, personally, do we?
I think we just have to make sure that they don’t fuck or die.
Ah. Good. Because I’m having a Walden’s Pond moment.
You have a pond?
You know I found something out about Walden’s Pond - it was five minutes from his mom’s house. He would go over there and get supplies.
So where are you?
(confused) Here?
No, where do you go to college?
Oh, I’m not, I don’t go. I’m done with college. But I went here... (does a flourish) --when I was younger.
Weird! For some reason I thought you HAD to be in college to do this.
Nope...I just wanted to get out of the city and I know the director of the summer program, so she hooked it up...and it had room and board...and I’m working the events to make more money.
Wow, you’re super responsible.  109
No. I’m not. (pause) It wasn’t that long ago that I went here. I’m only twenty-seven. The girl doesn’t care. Two young-ish looking dancers looking confused and carrying lots of luggage.
Fuck. I don’t know any answers. Don’t ask me! INT. COLLEGE CAMPUS. DANCE STUDIO. AFTERNOON. Frances walks in to the back of a class. It’s mostly aged students. A Dance Teacher approaches Frances.
Are you with the program?
Yeah, I’m assisting.
Oh great, you’re one of the teachers?
Um, no, not, I’m RAing and just - but I’m a dancer -
- Oh, I’m so sorry.
What?
We can’t let Resident Assistants take class.
But I’m not just an RA.
I’m so sorry, I don’t make the rules.
I’m a dancer. And I went here. 84. walk up 109 college-  112 113 85.
I’m so sorry, I have to start class...

location: COLLEGE CAMPUS. DANCE STUDIO. A LITTLE LATER. 110

text: Frances is watches the students taking the class that she not allowed to take. They’re really good. It’s simultaneously inspiring and depressing.
Frances caters, serving tiny food on big plates; pours wi into empty glasses.
Frances is back in to get more food. A chef looks at her suggestively:
You're a really good waitress.
I’m not a waitress. I just pour.
Frances drinks with the catering people. It’s a college b They are all wearing white shirts and black pants. They a all younger than her.
Okay, I have one: Who do you have to apologize to? Everyone thinks.
I'll go: Everyone I've talked shit about over the past year. People laugh.
I owe a bed and breakfast money...
No, that’s not the same.  86.
Frances walks into a dark dorm building. Stumbles towards room. A very annoyed looking girl is waiting for her ther
(loud whisper) You were supposed to be on duty ten minutes ago!
(normal voice) Sorry, I was -

Frances tiptoes around the other girl and into her room. 115 INT. DORM. FRANCES’ ROOM. NIGHT. 115 Frances flops down on her single bed. The room is totally undecorated, a college dorm room in the summer. The weird blonde wooden furniture.
Frances’ wakes up in the dark. She gets out of bed and wa down the hallway. Goes to the bathroom. On the walk back her room, she sees a Younger Girl crying.
Are you okay?
Yeah. Frances hesitates. Then decides the girl needs someone:
(sitting down next to her) I’m just going to sit here, okay?
You don’t have to do that.
I’m just going to, though. Frances sits and the Younger Girl cries.  Revision (05/14/2012) 87.

location: COLLEGE STUDENT CENTER. COMPUTER BANK. DAY. 117

text: Frances stands at one of three computers, the other two a taken. She checks her e-mail and looks at the joint Japan blog that Sophie and Patch have. A student looks on:
Are you going to study abroad there?
Oh I’m not a student. There’s no more abroad.
I’m half Japanese.
My best friend kind of lives there now. She drifts off. The student looks slightly annoyed.
(re: computer) Are you done?
Frances smokes a cigarette. A campus security guard comes of the woods.
You can’t smoke here!
(dropping her cigarette) Oh sorry --
-- No, don’t put it out! God damn it! They scuffle for the butt.
The co-ordinater of the catering company is giving assignments. He’s standing with Frances and pointing to t back of a woman’s head at the party.  120 Revision (05/14/2012) 88.
Famous how?
She’s a senator or a congresswoman or something. She’s important.
I should read the news more.
Your job tonight is to follow her. Just make sure she’s taken care of. She just gave the school a TON of money. You don’t leave until she leaves - got it?

Frances, in her catering uniform, stands behind the Congresswoman during the reception after the auction. Frances gets the Congresswoman different drinks and foods always with her. The Congresswoman flirts with a Young Ma Frances tries to not pay attention.
(sexily) Well when I went here it was all girls. To meet a boy you had to take the “Fuck Truck” to Hoboken.
(interrupting) You went here? Excuse me. You went to here?
Yes.
Oh my god, that makes so much sense! I knew you looked familiar. You were on the freakin’ brochures! I’m Frances, I went here.
Nice to meet you, Frances.
You too! Sorry, sorry. I’m not really supposed to talk to you...I’m pouring.
Ah, yes.
(confidentially) You're very inspiring.
Frances stands behind the Congresswoman and the Very Youn Man. Holds a wine bottle. Frances hears a girl crying and a man saying:
Don’t cry, baby, don’t cry, baby.
You don’t care!
I care.
You bought the CHEAPEST auction thing. THE CHEAPEST.
I didn’t even go here! Frances drifts in the direction of the fight. She turns a corner: It’s Sophie who’s crying. Patch consoling her. Frances ca believe it. Stares. Then retreats.
Frances is trying to avoid being seen by Sophie and Patch Sophie walks straight up to the Congresswoman. Frances hi behind her:
(drunkenly) You gave a GREAT speech, but I seriously can’t believe you’re an independent, because that’s bullshit.
(embarrassed) Sorry. Sophie, let’s go.  90.
I went here. I thought you were great. I made him give money.
Well, good. Nice to meet you.
We live in Japan. So it’s like crazy we're here.
That’s wonderful that you came all the way back for the auction.
I WISH. No, we're in New York for a funeral. His grandpa. I wanted to come here. He drove. But it was MY idea.
Oh...I’m sorry for your loss.
It’s okay. His grandpa had a second family in Germany.
(stern) Sophie, let’s go.
(to the Congresswoman) I loved meeting you. A real honor. (indicating Patch) This douche is my affianced.
Ah.
We're engaged.
(from across the room)
All eyes go to Frances.
Sophie and Frances talk. Frances keeps pouring wine for t Congresswoman. Sophie is messy drunk.  gl.
It’s not engaged engaged.
Right. What?
We're back for going to a funeral. I would have called - but you’re touring with the company.
(lying) Yeah, I was, but you know, I needed a break and I thought it would be so funny to come back to the college for the summer.
It is funny! In a great way.
Yeah. And just making extra money with this kind of gig.
Yeah. The Congresswoman continues to flirt with the Young Man.
(a little too loudly) What a slut.
Are you okay? Do you need some food?
(grabs a mini quiche) I‘1l just eat this.
I really didn’t expect to see you.
Ditto.
It’s almost hard to be happy about it because I didn’t have any time to anticipate it.  124 125 Revision (05/14/2012) 92.
(like in a bar trying to pick up a girl) Let’s get out of here.
I can’t. I have to shadow this woman -- she’s my...ward. The Congresswoman is full on making out with the Young Ma
The Congresswoman gets into her car with the Young Man. Frances waits for the car door to close. She breaths a si of relief. Sophie and Patch are fighting as they get into their car.
I’m not going back to New York. I don’t want to go to the funeral tomorrow.
You have to go.

I’m hanging out with Frances. We’re going to the mall. Frances climbs into the back seat. INT. PATCH’S CAR. NIGHT. 125 Frances sits in the backseat. Patch drives and Sophie is the front seat. Sophie is still wasted:
I’m bringing Frances to the funeral.
(to Sophie) I don’t want to go to the funeral.
You didn’t even know your grandpa. You didn’t hang out.
It’s a funeral. It doesn’t matter.  Revision (05/14/2012) 93.
If you’re so broken up about it why did we go to the auction tonight?
I DON’T EVEN WANT YOU HERE!
You were wasted, I wasn’t going to let you drive.
(turning around) Frances, what do you think?
About what?
(to Frances) You don’t need to answer.
How sad were you really when your Grandpa died?
Pretty sad. Yeah.
(pause) Well, I wasn’t. (to Patch) And I don’t see why you should be.
Oh, this is me, right up here. My dorm. Patch pulls up, Frances gets out. Patch and Sophie are st fighting.
(taking in her environment ) “Chuggins.” We never lived in this dorm.
I know. It’s like the life I never had! Anyway. Congratulations? (MORE )
On the engagement? (pause) And sorry for your loss.
(to Patch) You are so fucking selfish.
Goodnight, Frances.
Don’t talk to her, don’t look at her. She’s my friend. She doesn’t even like you.
I like you...
(to Frances) I like you too, Frances. Patch pulls away. Frances’ face “what the fuck just happened?”
Frances is asleep. She is woken up by an insistent knocki at her door. It’s Sophie. She’s crying.
Hey, hey, come in.
Can I stay?
Of course. Come. Stay.
Sophie is sitting on the bed, alone. There is a tapping o the door. She opens it. Frances is carrying two cups of tea.
It’s made in the microwave, but it’s good.
Thank you...I hope it’s okay I borrowed lounge wear.  128 95.
No, of course. Sophie takes her tea and they both sit cross-legged on th bed.
(takes a sip of the tea, looks green) I think...
Oh, shit, here - Frances puts a trashcan in front of her, Sophie throws up
They lay side by side in a single bed. The bedside light on.
I’m sorry I was so drunk I threw up.
I'm sorry I live in a dorm with a single bed. Sophie laughs.
Here, lay on the outside.
Okay. They switch places.
Put one foot on the floor. It helps you if you have the spins.
I used to throw up all the time when I was pregnant.
You were pregnant?
In Japan. For a few weeks. Then I miscarried which was cool.  Revision (05/14/2012) 96.
Wow.
I mean, that sounds crass - miscarriage is not cool.
Would you have had it?
No.
Are you going to marry Patch?
No.
I can’t believe that pregnant is no longer crazy.
I don’t want to stay in Tokyo. I hate it there.
Really?
Yeah. And then when I got pregnant I was just like “get me the fuck out.”
But your blog looks so happy.
I don’t think my mom would read it if it were about depression.
My mom would. They laugh.
I was telling the truth. I like Patch. I don’t hate him.
I know.  Revision (05/14/2012) 97.
I’m sorry about...It’s just if something funny happens on the way to the deli, you’1ll only tell one person and that will be Patch. And I’1l never hear about it.
(sort of taking it in, sort of not, after a beat) Fuck I’m tired. Frances turns off the light.
It’s bedtime for all good children.
I want to leave Patch and leave Tokyo and come back to New York.
You should!
I’m going to.
I could...I don’t know. I could help you. I was going to say “you could live with me,” but I don’t have a home. Ha.
I am going to do it.
Fuck yeah, girl.
I miss my job. And I miss old skyscrapers.
Maybe we’1ll both move back to New York at the same time. We'll be like women who re-discover themselves after a divorce.
That’s what my mom did.
Oh, yeah, sorry.
I think it will be great.
We should get apartments close to each other - in Brooklyn.
Yeah. That’s what we’ll do. (pause) I've always felt so competitive with you.
(surprised) Really? I don’t think I realized we were competitive. They are quiet for a minute.
Fran?
Yes?
Can you...I know it’s not my bed, but...
What?
Can you take off your socks?
Oh, yeah, sure.
It’s just - socks in bed.
Right. Gross. Frances takes off her socks and lies down again. Quiet.
I love you Frances. Goodnight.  129 130 99.
I love you Sophie. Goodnight.

Sophie is moving around the room quietly. Frances is stil sleeping. After she finishes getting dressed, she writes a note. CLOSE on the note as Sophie leaves. Frances wakes up a second later. She looks around confuse Sees the note. Reads it.

I’m sorry I was so drunk last night, but thank you for being nice to me which I know you were even though I don’t remember it. All I know is you don’t have a trash can this morning so it must have been bad! Ha ha. I love you. I’ve got to get back to this funeral in New York. Call me when you're awake! My phone works in the states and there aren’t any charges or anything. xoxo Sophie Without putting on shoes or a robe, Frances runs 130 downstairs and out to the parking lot in bare feet just t see Patch’s car turning out of the lot and onto the main road. Frances runs after the car onto the road.
(calling) Sophie! Sophie! But Sophie doesn’t see or hear her. She’s gone. Frances l down at her bare feet and looks back up to the road. BLACK.  Revision (05/14/2012) 100.
Frances walking with her backpack and bomber jacket early the morning. She’s carrying a coffee mug, like she made i home. Or at least thought ahead enough to bring it with h and get it filled.
Gets out of the subway by City Hall. Walks through a hall of dancers we’ve seen her in before - maybe she’s dancing But nope. She’s -
Frances busily working at a development office. With Coll - she took the job she had rejected before. Making phone calls, doing things on spreadsheets, etc.
Frances choreographs something in the park during lunch. She's enjoying herself. Dances. Takes a bite of a sandwich that she produced from paper bag. She’s brought a bagged lunch. A female co-work
We’re back in five, Frances. *
Thanks!
Frances is finishing up the day. People are leaving. She looks at the clock. Makes a phone call:
Yes, hi, this is Frances...yes, “Frances for tonight”...ha thanks!...I just wanted to double check that we’re still on for me bringing my guys in a little * early...okay! Great! See you in thirty!
An older woman lets Frances into the space.
I think the other two groups will be here by six forty five.  136 137 138 101.
We'll be done by then, thanks! Frances puts her stuff down and physically explores the place.
A lot of young dancers come in, all female, around twenty them. They all hug Frances, warm up, and run through a co of sequences. Frances checks the lights and sound boards.

One company finishes up. Come out and bow. Lights go down Frances is up in the sound/light booth. Trades places wit the person who was there before her. She breathes hard, in and out, and turns the lights on an the sound up. Frances continues to run boards while her dancers perform There is a small audience. Frances is beaming.

People are milling around, talking with their families an friends. It’s kind of a reception. It’s one of those thin where there was hardly anyone there who doesn’t know some who was performing. Colleen is there, Rachel is there, Frances’ ex-boyfriend, is there, Lev and a different hot girl. Benji approaches Frances.
Hey, that was great.
Aw, thanks Ben. I like a lot of ladies dancing.
Yeah, at times it reminded me of...Antonioni’s Zabriskie Point... (beat) Undateable.
No, I meant me that time.
Oh, yeah, Zabriskie Point.
But also true. Meaning I’m not dating anyone. Undateable. Same difference.
Ah.
Are you really, still, are you - undateable?

You mean am I, oh, yes. Yes I am. Very undateable. Benji and Frances have a half-moment. Frances greets more people, takes pictures, laughs. Colle is there, congratulates her. This is the high point of Frances’ twenty-seven years. Then, across the room, Frances sees Sophie. At first Soph doesn’t see her. Patch enters frame and puts his arm arou her. She holds up her hand to someone. She has a ring.

You guys got married! Frances looks away, surveys the crowd of people who came see her show. She smiles. She looks back. Sophie is watching her. They catch each other’s eye and kind of smile. It’s the moment that Frances has always wanted. They are sharing a life-long inside joke.
Who are you making eyes at?

That’s Sophie. She’s my best friend. They keep looking at each other, kind of laughing, kind o emotional. No one breaks.  139 140 141 103. CLOSE on Sophie looking at Frances. CLOSE on Frances looking on Sophie.
Nothing special.

CLOSE on Frances’ hand writing something. It’s her name. Frances cuts out the name from the sheet of paper. She’s sitting at the kitchen table of a small just-moved-into pretty empty apartment. She walks out and trots down a flight of stairs to a bank of mailboxes. She finds 2B and opens it. CLOSE on Frances sliding the piece of paper into the mail slot. It doesn’t quite fit. She has to fold it to get it into the space. Once it is in, it just reads:
We hold on the title. Roll CREDITS over the image.
